This applies to distributions made to individuals who were ordered or called to active duty for a period exceeding 179 days or for an indefinite period, and the distribution is made from amounts attributable to employer contributions made pursuant to elective deferrals. The Guardsmen and Reservists Financial Relief Act of 2005 allows penalty-free withdrawals from retirement plans for individuals called to active duty for at least 179 days. This provision applies to individuals ordered or called to active duty after September 11, 2001, and before September 12, 2007, with distributions made during the active duty period. The text chunk amends various sections of the Internal Revenue Code related to penalty-free withdrawals from retirement plans for individuals called to active duty. It includes changes to subclauses, subparagraphs, and distributions under section 72(t)(2)(G). The amendment made by this section allows penalty-free distributions from retirement plans for individuals called to active duty after September 11, 2001. Refunds or credits of overpayments resulting from this amendment can be claimed within one year of the enactment of this Act, even if prevented by other laws.
